newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan to stay in 16MB DRAMs despite price war.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan to stay in 16MB DRAMs despite price war.

text.p: Taiwan chipmakers said on Thursday that a shakeup in the global memory-chip market had run its course, and forecast profits for the hard-hit 16-megabit sector despite a long and precarious downturn in prices.

Several Taiwan semiconductor companies said production of 16MB dynamic random-access memory chips, called DRAMs, would continue to dominate the island's chip-making industry rather than the costlier, next-generation 64MB DRAMs.

"We have no plan to follow other foreign firms' suit to cut back production in 16-megabit DRAMs," said a spokeswoman at TI-Acer Inc, a joint venture of Taiwan's computer giant Acer Inc and U.S. giant Texas Instruments.
"In fact, we have decided to concentrate on production of 16-megabit DRAMs this year. We intend to run at full capacity. The price for 16-Megabit DRAMs has stabilised," she said.
Winbond Electronics Corp, Taiwan's third largest semiconductor maker, has even more ambitious plans.
"Not only will we retain our total investment but also we will continue our expansion plans," Winbond spokesman Liu Chung-kwang said by telephone.
Winbond planned to start making 16MB DRAMs in 1997.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, the island's largest semiconductor maker, would also start producing 16MB DRAMs or more advanced products for Fujitsu Ltd at a new plant between 1997 and 2000.

DRAMs are rapidly becoming a commodity in the microcomputer industry. Because the amount of memory installed in a computer is a key measure of its speed and efficiency, market demand to cram more megabits of memory onto a chip is enormous.
Many Japanese semiconductor makers have announced cutbacks in memory-chip investments in recent months and begun shifting production to 64MB DRAMs following a fall in 16MB chip prices.

While 4MB DRAMS are industry dinosaurs and 16MB technology may have seen better days, the market has yet to fully embrace the far more expensive 64-megabit benchmark -- leaving plenty of life for manufacturers in the 16MB range.

"Local makers may still find profits in the 16-megabit market this year. But 16-megabit DRAMs will be a short-lived product," said Nikko Securities research chief Michael Hung. "They'll have to shift to 64-megabit chips sooner or later."
Analysts say a shift to 64MB chips is inevitable.
TI-Acer has stopped making 4MB DRAM chips altogether, phasing them out since June due to plunging prices.
Both TI-Acer and Winbond said they planned to shift to 64MB chips from the second half of 1997.
"I don't see a huge demand for 64-megabit chips at the moment," the TI-Acer spokeswoman said. "We are not eager to jump into the market."
Liu said Winbond, which has a 64MB production technology agreement with Japan's Toshiba Corp, will use the higher technology to produce its lower-tech 16MB DRAMs next year.
Toshiba has said Winbond may start mass-production of 64MB DRAMs in Taiwan by the end of 1998, but a final decision has not been made.
